Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Investigating Initiation and History of the Aleutian Arc and Composition and Significance of North Pacific Seafloor via Dredge Samples from the R/V Sonne
Award.AbstractNarration:
Subduction is a fundamental tectonic process that shapes the Earth's physical and chemical evolution and has many important potential human impacts, including seismic and volcanic hazards, as well as mineral resources, which are common products of subduction magmatism. As a result, subduction-related processes are the subject of broad public interest and widespread investigation in the geosciences. Despite almost a century of research on the Alaska-Aleutian subduction system, several key questions remain unanswered including how and when the subduction zone was formed and to what extent the subducting Pacific plate contributes to the creation of magma generated beneath Alaska-Aleutian volcanoes. This project will allow a group of U.S. scientists from the University of South Carolina and the University of Wisconsin-Madison to precisely determine the timing of Aleutian arc formation and to characterize the products that are entering and have erupted from this active volcanic arc. This is a collaborative effort involving graduate and undergraduate students, post-docs, and researchers from Germany, Russia and the United States. All data from this project will be made available to the public.

The project has two broadly related themes: 1) Constraining the timing of subduction initiation and early evolution of the Aleutian arc, and 2) Characterizing subduction inputs to both the Aleutian and Kamchatka arcs and relating them to the processes controlling arc magma formation. Analyses of samples from Expedition SO249 of the German R/V Sonne as part of the German-Russian BERING project will provide constraints on the timing of Aleutian arc formation and the geochemistry of the early arc products. The project will also obtain geochemical data for north Pacific seafloor samples adjacent to the western Aleutian arc, including sites both east and west of the northern Emperor seamounts. This study will help better understand geochemical linkages between subduction input and volcanic output, and will provide new constraints and significantly improve models of arc magma genesis for the Aleutians and Kamchatka.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Subduction is the geologic process where one tectonic plate sinks beneath another into the hot interior of the Earth. Subduction has many human impacts, especially hazards from seismic and volcanic activity that are a constant threat to population centers and commerce. Subduction also plays a key role in shaping the earth's surface and is important in the formation of continents and the mineral resources they contain. As a result, subduction-related processes are the subject of broad public and scientific interest. The major objective of this project was to analyze the chemical compositions of rock samples of North Pacific seafloor and to use the data to better understand how the composition of subducting seafloor of the Pacific Plate is transferred to magmas that are formed in the Aleutian and Kamchatka subduction zones and are erupted as lavas of the Aleutian and Kamchatka volcanic arcs.

An important finding of the project is that volcanic rocks that make up North Pacific seafloor have absorbed chemical characteristics of seawater that are in key ways distinct from those that have been documented by other studies. In particular, we found that a large proportion of North Pacific seafloor rocks have absorption little of the element strontium (Sr) from seawater, but significant quantities of the rare-earth element neodymium (Nd). The source of the Nd is revealed by ratios among the different isotopes, which point to a source in seawater. The resulting data pattern shows widely variable isotope ratios for Nd in our samples, but nearly constant isotope ratios for Sr. This is the opposite of the expected pattern, which is also observed in a separate set of North Pacific seafloor samples included our study.  

Another important finding of the project is that lead (Pb) in North Pacific seafloor rocks is a type (again, revealed by isotope ratios) that is unlike the Pb in lavas produced by Aleutian and Kamchatka volcanism. In this case, the implication is that Pb from the subducting North Pacific seafloor that contributes to magmas that feed Aleutian and Kamchatka volcanoes cannot have been from the very top of the subducting plate, which is where our samples are from. Instead, the Pb that is transferred from the subducting plate to Aleutian and Kamchatka magmas must have come predominantly from the interior of the subducting plate where there is little or no Pb from seawater. The implication is that there must have been more extensive heating and melting of the subducting plate than is generally allowed by thermal models of subduction zones.    

Graduate students working on this and other similar projects in our laboratories develop scientific and technical skills that put them on a variety of successful career paths. Some pursue traditional careers for geologists in resource extraction, especially in the oil-and-gas industry. Another career path made possible by the experiences of our students is in the area of analytical chemistry. For their research, our students work in ultra-clean laboratories and with mass spectrometers and electron microscopes. As a result, they become skilled in the operation of analytical instrumentation and the processing and use of the data that such instrumentation produces. Three recent PhD students with these skills have taken jobs in the federal government or with federal contractors at the Savannah River National Laboratory in South Carolina, the NASA Johnston Space Center in Houston, and most recently at the Airforce Technical Applications Center in Florida. Through projects such as this one, our laboratories become the last piece of the educational pipeline that creates the scientific and technical workforce that is in demand in the laboratories of American industry and government.
